The Senate, on 3 June 1988, adjourned to 22 August 1988 unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 2 June 1988, the Senate met in the new Parliament House on Monday, 22 August 1988, at 4 p.m.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1988 the Senate referred to the Court of Disputed Returns certain questions relating to the place in the Senate representing New South Wales to which William Robert Wood was returned in the 1987 election. On 12 May 1988, in answer to those questions, the Court found that the place in the Senate was vacant. I presented to the Senate on 17 May 1988 the reasons for judgment of the Court in relation to that finding. I now present the judgment and reasons relating to those questions.

INTERJECT.PARA: Since the Senate last met, the Court has made two further orders in relation to the matter referred to it. On 7 June 1988 the Court ordered that the Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales undertake a further counting and recounting of the ballot papers cast for candidates in the election in that State, for the purpose of determining the candidate entitled to be elected to the vacant place, and that the Australian Electoral Officer for the State report that result to the Court. On 21 July 1988, having received that report, the Court ordered that Irina Patsi Dunn be declared elected as a senator for New South Wales in the vacant place in the Senate.

I now present to the Senate the orders of the Court of 7 June and 21 July 1988, together with reasons relating to the first of those orders. DEBATE.TITLE: MESSAGE FROM THE QUEEN AND ADDRESS BY THE GOVERNOR-GENERAL

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a copy of a message from Her Majesty the Queen, and the address of His Excellency the Governor-General, delivered earlier today in the Great Hall, to mark the inaugural sittings of the two Houses in this building. I table the documents. In order that there may be a full written record of today's events I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to incorporate the document in Hansard. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: The document read as follows-

ADDRESS BY HIS EXCELLENCY THE RIGHT HONOURABLE SIR NINIAN STEPHEN, GOVERNOR-GENERAL OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA, ON THE OCCASION OF THE FIRST MEETING OF THE PARLIAMENT IN THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE, CANBERRA ON MONDAY, 22 AUGUST 1988
I begin with a message from Her Majesty the Queen, sent on this historic occasion:

I am delighted to learn that the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia today begins its work in its new home. I have happy memories of the opening ceremony which, for me, was a highlight of the bicentennial year. I take this opportunity to send to the people of the Commonwealth of Australia my heartfelt wishes for their prosperity and happiness and am confident that the deliberations of the Parliament in this new building will be directed to that end.
Elizabeth R.
22 August 1988

Nations, like people, take their shape, their style and character, from their inheritance and from their environment. If today is, for Australia, historic, it is because this occasion, today, in the nation's capital, is the outcome of all that has shaped Australia over the past 200 years.

For thousands of years the first inhabitants of this then isolated continent lived their lives free of the need of principles for the governance of a nation in the modern world. But from the first day of that landing of the First Fleet in Sydney Cove 200 years ago, perhaps in all history the most curious of beginnings of any nation, a policy has been evolving: from governor's rule of a penal settlement, through stages of representative and then responsible government, first colonial and then federal and national, to this day; the day when, for the first time, the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia will sit in its own permanent home in the national capital.

Today when the members of this Parliament take their seats in the two chambers of this Parliament House they will know that in doing so they mark a momentous milestone in the long history of Australian democracy. That spirit of democracy asserted itself in colonial days and was the sure foundation upon which our federal nation was created. It has been dear to us ever since.
This is the third home of the Parliament of the Commonwealth. Our Constitution makes short work of Parliament's place of sitting; almost abruptly it declares, in section 125, that:
The Parliament shall sit at Melbourne until it meet at the seat of Government.

And sit in Melbourne it did, in borrowed splendour, for a quarter of a century, in that great palace at the top of Bourke Street, Victoria's own Parliament House, while the seat of government was duly determined and a provisional Parliament House build there, in Canberra.

It sat in Melbourne from its first day of sitting on the afternoon of 9th May 1901, until late in the afternoon of 24th March 1927. Then, both to the intensely emotional strains of Auld Lang Syne and to the no less intense relief of long dispossessed Victorian legislators, it adjourned; to meet next, in May 1927, in Canberra in that much more modest, white stuccoed brick building down the hill which, to the minds of at least three generations of Australians, has been the symbol of our federal parliamentary democracy.
Now, some sixty years on, Federal Parliament moves again but Australia's long traditions of democracy continue unchanged.

As the measure of these things goes in the world community of nations, Australia is among the most enduring continuous democracies that the world has known, even if we reckon only from the time of Federation, which incidentally, does scant justice to our own vigorous colonial democracies of the second half of last century.

Apart from Britain, from which our free institutions spring, and the two great democracies of North America, no one of the now many nations of Asia, Africa, or the Americas, and only two, I think, of all the nations of Europe can count a similar uninterrupted span of over 87 years of democratic government-years of governments which have come to power by the free vote of the people and which have at all times held themselves effectively accountable to the people.

This great new Parliament House is itself a celebration of our democracy, of the success on this continent of what, in the heady days of Britain's reform Bills of the last century, was thought to be a too hazardous experiment: the giving of the vote to all of the people. We inherited from Britain the traditions of parliamentary democracy; we took from the United States its own bold experiment in federalism. Then, bolder still, we combined the two and produced a federal and parliamentary commonwealth of which this building now becomes the symbol.

Perhaps we Australians haven't in the past been very strong on symbols; at least away from the sporting field. We like to think we don't place much store by them or by the titles of office. That has always been the style of our democracy. But here on Capital Hill, we now have a symbol we can't ignore, one that will remind the Australian people of the weight of responsibility that rests on those it elects to Parliament, that will affirm to all who are elected to represent the nation in this house of the Parliament that it is upon the quality of their deliberations and the wisdom of their decisions that this nation's future and the welfare of all Australians, now and long into the future, will depend. May the splendour of this building inspire them, and the nation, to high achievement and to noble goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate, I will thank Her Majesty for the message.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE: MOTION OF THANKS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion of thanks relating to the presentation of gifts to the Commonwealth Parliament and to those people associated with the planning and construction of the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following resolutions be agreed to-

(1) That the Senate expresses its thanks and appreciation of the Parliaments, Governments and peoples of those countries, States and Territories and to those organisations which have so graciously presented gifts to Australia's new Parliament House and extends a warm welcome to those Presiding Officers and representatives who are present today.
(2) That the Senate extends its sincere thanks to the following persons and organisations associated with the planning and construction of the new Parliament House:
(a) Mitchell/Giurgola and Thorp Architects who designed it,
(b) the Parliament House Construction Authority, Concrete/Holland Joint Venture and all contractors and workers who built it,
(c) the artists, craftsmen and craftswomen who advised on and assisted in its furnishing and decoration, and

(d) the members of the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, all past and present members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, officers of the National Capital Development Commission, parliamentary and other staff,
for their endeavours in providing a magnificent permanent building for the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Mr President, on the historic first sitting day in this building, I should like to take the opportunity to express the appreciation of the Parliament, the Government and the people of Australia to the parliaments, governments and peoples of those countries, States and Territories and those organisations which have generously presented gifts to Australia's new Parliament House. It is particularly pleasing that representatives of many of those donors, including the presiding officers of other parliaments, are able to be with us today.

The internal spaces of the building now display the embroideries, tapestries, paintings, maps and other gifts, sent here from the four corners of the world and the four corners of Australia. They are already part of this building's own history. Outside there are sculptures, benches and trees presented by our friends to add to the environment of the new building.

It is appropriate, Mr President, that I make special mention of the gifts located within this chamber: the vice-regal chair, a gift from the Parliament of the United Kingdom; the distinguished visitors chair, from the New Zealand Parliament; your own chair, Mr President, which is a gift from the Canadian Senate; and the Hansard table, a gift from the Government, Parliament and people of Tasmania. All these gifts will remind us and future generations of parliamentarians of our international ties, our bonds with the Australian States and the responsibility that we owe to the Australian people to cherish and preserve our system of parliamentary democracy. In expressing my thanks to those who join us for this special day and to those who have presented gifts, I believe they share our pride in this great building. Their generosity indicates the respect in which Australia's system of parliamentary democracy is held.

Mr President, the care and dedication that have gone into the construction of this building give us a lasting debt of gratitude to all those men and women who have been involved. To the architects, Romaldo Giurgola and Richard Thorp, we say thank you for your vision in designing a building of which all Australians, present and future, can be justly proud. We thank also the Chairman, members and the Chief Executive of the Parliament House Construction Authority and their staff for their hard work and dedication throughout the construction phase of the building. To Concrete Holland Joint Venture, the Construction Manager, and all the other contractors and workers involved in the project who, by the labour of their minds and bodies, have made it the remarkable reality it is, we also express our gratitude.

We also recall the work which has been done by the members of the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, officers of the National Capital Development Commission, and parliamentary and other staff in the building. The new Parliament House embodies the work of over 10,000 men and women, with contributions from individuals and manufacturers from every State and Territory. It is a national showcase demonstrating the skills and energy of the Australian work force.

Mr President, the integration of Australian art and craft into the new Parliament House is a key part of the building's architectural expression. The artists, craftsmen and craftswomen have created significant works now displayed throughout the building. The `meeting place' mosaic designed by Papunya artist Michael Nelson Tjakamarra and fabricated by masons William McIntosh, Aldo Rossi and Franco Colussi stands in the centre of the ceremonial pool at the heart of the forecourt and is appropriately the first work of art visitors see when approaching this building. In the Great Hall the tapestry by 14 weavers of the Victorian Tapestry Workshop dramatically depicts an Australian coastal landscape created from paintings by Arthur Boyd. In the first floor public gallery the embroidery designed by South Australian artist Kay Lawrence and produced by more than 1,000 members of the Embroiderers Guild of Australia narrates the history of Australians' involvement with the land. The marquetry designed by South Australian Tony Bishop and interpreted by Sydney craftsman Michael Retter can be found in the formal entrance foyer and elsewhere in the building.

There are many more craftspeople and artists who have contributed to the national character of the new Parliament House. I instance Tasmanian woodworker Kevin Perkins and others who have handcrafted tables and desks for the use in principal suites. Other important works of Australian woodcraft include the King table in the Reception Hall and display cases in the foyer exhibiting constitutional documents. We could continue enumerating at length for, wherever we look, we see work worthy of praise. To all those who worked to give us this home for our Parliament I express my sincere thanks. I hope that many Australians will have the opportunity to share our gratitude-and indeed excitement-when visiting this Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the expression of thanks to the very many people who have contributed to this building. I agree with him and with you, Mr President, that it is very appropriate that representatives of the Parliaments, Governments and people who have made contribution to this place are here today to hear the expressions of thanks and the formal motion which will make them a part of our permanent Senate record.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there is some contention about this building, not least among the senators and members who will occupy it. I think it is an indication of the conservative nature of human beings that so many of us are finding it difficult to fit in to our new and very splendid environment. I have absolutely no doubt that those who have contributed the various items that have been referred to by the Leader of the Government hope that those items will inspire us to do our work in a fitting way for Australia.

Concern has been expressed about the separation of Ministers from the back bench which is such a strong feature of the design of this building. However, that separation may lead legislators in this place to be more conscious of their role as legislators. I note that already some retired public servants have written about the possible uses of the new committee rooms and the change that that might induce. It may well be that the form of Parliament House will have a significant impact on the way in which this Parliament operates. With respect to all of those who have been thanked, I can say on behalf of the Opposition that we support the sentiments which have been expressed by Senator Button.

I do think, however, that it is also fitting to note that, in the construction of this place, the very enormous cost was considerably expanded by the very frequent and absurd restrictive work practices which afflicted the building site. The group which was omitted from the motion of thanks was the Opposition's waste watch committee, the rorts task force, which incurred considerable unpopularity in drawing attention to some of the quite extraordinarily wasteful things which occurred on this site. I remind the Senate, as we pass this motion of thanks, that this very expensive building was rendered far more expensive by some of the extraordinary practices which were carried on in this place, unfortunately in common with other commercial building sites in this country. We found, when examining this matter, that people were reluctant to talk about what was happening because they were frightened of reprisals.

I remind the Senate that as this building was being built people were being paid a specific allowance just to show up at work; that nicking off-that practice of arriving at work and not actually staying to do a day's work-was common; that there were endless health and safety strikes which were extremely wasteful; and that a climbing time of two hours was allowed for crane drivers who took about 45 seconds actually to climb the cranes in question. I know that that list could be extended very considerably: I refer to the clothing allowance which was paid no matter how little time was spent on the site, to the excessive site allowances, and to the extraordinary range of strikes which were so damaging to many of the contractors who worked here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Always the statesman, Fred; never the partisan politician!

—I mention that because it was a very strong feature of the erection of this building. I note that the Foreign Affairs Minister designate, who I am sure will be leaving this place very frequently-and for that we are all mercifully relieved-seeks to intervene. In what is a most splendid building, full of the most splendid objects and artefacts, I express that one element of regret: it was made so much more expensive for the people of Australia than otherwise would have been required. In all other respects, I heartily join in the sentiments which have been expressed by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate the Australian Democrats with the motion of appreciation moved by Senator Button in regard to those countries, States and organisations which presented gifts to the new Parliament House. Senator Button has already referred to many of those gifts. Certainly, the antique maps and aluminium sculptures, the trees and the tapestries, the chairs and Chinese lanterns, the crystal glasses and candelabra, the teak benches, bronze busts, books on young Australians, stone lions and porcelain figures-to say nothing of clocks and wall hangings of every kind-will adorn the new Parliament House and its environs thanks to the generosity of the rest of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Many countries of very different political systems and ideologies, as well as Australian States and national organisations, have presented the Parliament with a wonderful array of exotic and beautiful gifts. It is particularly appropriate that we share the chamber today with representatives of many of the countries that have donated those gifts. The President's chair, the Hansard tables, coats of arms, a distinguished visitors chair, paintings, sundials and drinking fountains, the vice-regal chair in the Senate and dinner services and furniture for special rooms will become priceless possessions of those of us who work here and those who will follow us. Essentially, these gifts ensure that we want for nothing as far as decorations, accoutrements and creature comforts are concerned. They combine with the mosaic, the tapestry, the parquetry and so on produced by Australian artisans and artists to make this building truly unique and something that Australians can view and visit with pride.

In supporting this motion I echo the Governor-General's inauguration address by wishing us all well in this place of business and expressing the hope that the august and impressive surroundings which make up our permanent Parliament House lead us and our successors to draft and debate legislation in a true spirit of goodwill and concern for the well-being of the nation in the long term rather than our own short term political gains.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 4.20 p.m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Telecom keep sales check figures that indicate the accuracy of its service charges; if so, what percentage of Telecom customers are incorrectly charged, and of this number, what percentage are overcharged.
(2) What steps are being taken to improve the accuracy of service charging.
(3) Is Telecom discontinuing regular sales checks for business customers; if so, what are the reasons for discontinuing this service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on the advice of Telecom Australia, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom does keep sales check figures but not on a national basis. Sales check activities are the responsibility of decentralised Telecom district administrations and are not reported above this level. It is not possible to obtain these figures without diverting significant resources to a special investigation and this could not be justified.
(2) Major activities aimed at improving the accuracy of Telecom's rental charges include:
the introduction of automated systems which will reduce transcription errors and verify the accuracy of existing records on conversion from manual to automated systems;
revision of the Customer Services staff selection and accreditation processes;
the introduction of new training programs to better equip and recruit staff for Customer Services work; and
the introduction of automated text retrieval systems to facilitate more timely pricing advice to Customer Services staff.
(3) Telecom proposes to discontinue routine sales checks for business customers.

In the past, Telecom's billing system could not provide a breakdown of rental for equipment installed on telephone services. However, Telecom did physically inspect equipment at business customers' premises from time to time.

The new billing system being introduced nationally provides information on screen to enable prompt responses to business customers enquiring about charges for their equipment. Customers can also receive details of their equipment charges in regular or ad-hoc statements.
Inspections will still be performed where such action is warranted and is sought by the customer, and where normal billing procedures indicate some discrepancy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Council

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the expected saving in expenditure to be made from the abolition of the A.C.T. Schools Authority Council.
(2) Who or what will now carry out the functions formerly performed by the A.C.T. Schools Authority Council.
(3) What mechanism will be set up to allow parents and teachers to continue to have an involvement with the development of schools policy in the A.C.T.

(4) Have there been any moves to replace the A.C.T. Schools Authority Council representative, who formerly formed part of the selection committees for school principals; if so, who now fulfils this role.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of supporting the Schools Authority Council was $240,000 and no resources are now employed for this purpose. Some of the resources saved have been used to support new community and advisory functions. Net savings are estimated at $108,000.

Teachers Federation and Canberra Pre-School Society, an independent chairperson appointed by the Minister and 1 other Ministerial nominee.
(3) The statutory advisory committee will allow parents and teachers to continue to be involved in the development of schools policy in the A.C.T.

(4) School boards continue to have a role in the selection of school principals through their nominee on the advisory selection panels. At no stage have A.C.T. Schools Authority Council members, in that role, been members of advisory selection panels for school principal positions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian Government considered permitting representatives of the Australian Government to testify before United States Congressional Committees which are considering legislation which would affect Australia's commercial and foreign interests; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has considered permitting its representatives to testify before United States Congressional Committees but has concluded that there is no reason to depart from its present practice of dealing directly with individual members of committees and their staffs.

The rules of the House of Representatives and the Senate of the United States Congress do not preclude representatives of foreign governments testifying before a committee of the Congress. The issue of testimony by foreigners is decided by individual committee chairpersons and the practice varies between committees. On the whole, however, testimony by foreigners is unusual.

Apart from the doubtful utility of giving testimony, given the accessibility of committee members and their staffs to oral and written representations, an important contributing factor is whether Australian ministers or officials should place themselves under the jurisdiction of a foreign parliamentary body. I understand that this question also makes members of the Congress reluctant to ask for or agree to testimony by foreigners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are recent press reports that the Reserve Bank proposes to increase the bank's asset backing or gearing ratios from about 6 per cent to 8 per cent through an increase in share holder funds accurate.

(2) What is the estimate of the increase in overall cost to the banks of holding home loans under the proposal which is apparently based on a risk assessment that gives only a 50 per cent risk weight to mortgage loans.
(3) What effect has this proposal had on the proposed sale of the Defence Service Home Loans portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Reserve Bank currently measures the capital adequacy of banks using the simple ``capital-to-total assets'' ratio. Banks generally operate with capital ratios above 6 per cent measured on that basis. In the light of changes in the character of banking, in Australia and overseas countries, the Reserve Bank has been developing a new approach to the measurement of capital adequacy to take better account of the risk profile of a bank's business, including off-balance sheet activities. The Bank outlined its proposed risk ratio approach to the measurement of capital adequacy in a discussion paper circulated to banks in January 1988. At this stage no decision has been made about specific capital ratio standards under the proposed risk ratio framework. However, the Bank has given its endorsement to a proposal by the Basle Supervisors' Committee, based in the Bank for International Settlements, suggesting the adoption of a minimum standard ratio of ``Capital to weighted risk assets'' of 8 per cent as a basis for international convergence of capital standards.

(2) Under the proposed new capital adequacy framework, bank loans to private sector clients will generally be measured at their gross values and receive a 100 per cent weight. The proposed 50 per cent weight for owner-occupied housing fully secured against mortgages should work towards lower capital costs to banks in providing housing loans.

(3) There have been some press reports that this proposal has adversely affected the sale of the portfolio. However, I understand that it has not been considered to be a problem by the majority of interested parties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were the recently publicised negotiations with New Zealand concerning the merger of Qantas and Air New Zealand part of Government endeavours to build strong Trans-Tasman companies that can compete in the international markets.
(2) What progress has been made towards the development of a common trade practices policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The arrangements under the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement establish a predictable environment in which industries in both countries can take investment and planning decisions having regard to the wider trans-Tasman market.

However, the CER Agreement represents only one aspect of the Australian Government's broader efforts to encourage internationally competitive industries. It is a matter for individual enterprises to pursue opportunities within the Australia-New Zealand market in line with commercial judgment.

The recent discussions regarding a possible merger between Qantas, Australian Airlines and Air New Zealand were explanatory only and took place against the background of a rapidly changing world aviation scene, which is putting at risk the viability of national carriers operating in traditionally independent ways, and has forced airlines all around the world to cope with the challenges posed by the mega-carriers and the new competitive realities. There was however no agreement to merge the airlines, as several difficulties, such as the structural imbalance the merger would necessarily involve between Australian and New Zealand interests, were too formidable to justify it being pursued further at this time.

Notwithstanding this, the discussions demonstrated that common booking arrangements between Qantas and Air New Zealand, and joint marketing and joint purchasing would benefit both airlines through lower costs and efficiency gains. A close commercial alliance would also give the two airlines much greater bargaining capacity both with other countries and the mega-carriers.

The New Zealand Government is currently considering preliminary bids, by a number of interests, including Qantas, following approaches made by that Government inviting non-binding bids for the purchase of equity in Air New Zealand.

(2) At the meeting between Australian and New Zealand Ministers on the Review of the Australia- New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement held in Christchurch on 20-21 June 1988 it was agreed that from 1 July 1990 when full free trade between the two countries is achieved, anti-dumping measures would no longer be applied in respect of goods originating in either member state, subject to the necessary amendments in both countries' competition laws.

These amendments relate, inter alia, to misuse of market power or dominance where the conduct occurs in the other country and to extend the definition of market to apply to any market, not just the Australian or New Zealand markets.

In addition, the Deputy Prime Ministers of both countries signed on 1 July 1988 a Memorandum of Understanding on Harmonisation of Business Law which establishes a program for consideration of harmonisation of Australian and New Zealand legislation in a number of areas including:
consumer protection, particularly with respect to post-sale consumer protection, and consumer credit laws;
mutual assistance between regulatory agencies in the adminisration and enforcement of business laws;
further recognition and reciprocal enforcement of court decisions in each country, including enforcement of injunctions, orders for specific performance and revenue judgments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 19 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were there recent attempts by the International Whaling Commission (IWC) to stop Japan from killing 300 Minke whales in the Antarctic for so-called `scientific purposes'.

(2) Has the United States (U.S.) Department of Commerce announced that it intends to sanction Japan by cutting the Japanese fishing quota in U.S. waters by fifty per cent and is considering restrictions on imports of Japanese fish products into the United States; if so, would the Australian Government be prepared to support the United States' efforts to stop Japan's `scientific' whaling, by similarly restricting the access of Japanese fishing vessels to Australian waters, until such time as Japan stops its whaling; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The International Whaling Commission (IWC) agreed in 1982 to a moratorium on all commercial whaling to begin in 1986. However Article VIII of the Convention under which the IWC operates makes provision for countries to take whales under special permit for research purposes.

In March 1987, Japan submitted a proposal to the IWC for an annual take of 875 Antarctic whales (i.e. 825 Minke and 50 Sperm) under special research permits for at least the next 12 years. At the Annual Meeting of the IWC in June 1987 a resolution was passed recommending that Japan refrain from issuing such permits until the IWC Scientific Committee was able to resolve serious uncertainties identified in the proposal.

Japan then submitted a new proposal for a kill of 300 minke whales in the 1987/88 whaling season. At an extraordinary meeting of the IWC's scientific Committee set up to review Japan's proposal there was strong opposition from the majority of scientists present. Subsequently the U.K. proposed, and Australia and Sweden seconded, a resolution recommending that Japan refrain from taking the whales. It was adopted by a majority of 19 for, 6 against and 2 abstentions (6 countries failed to vote). Despite this resolution Japan ordered its whaling vessels to Antarctica where they took 273 of the planned 300 whales in early 1988.

(2) The United States has two legislative provisions for economic sanctions against countries `diminishing the effectiveness of the IWC'. The Packwood-Magnuson Amendment to the Fishery Conservation and Management Act provides for restriction of fishing allocations in the U.S.A. 200 mile fishing zone. The Pelly Amendment to the U.S. Fishermen's Protective Act provides for the prohibition of fisheries imports from offending countries. Certification of a country as `diminishing the effectiveness of the IWC' precedes consideration of sanctions against such countries.

At the last session of the IWC (Bournemouth U.K., 1987), Australia worked closely with the U.S.A. to establish specific criteria for the issuance of special permits under Article VIII of the Convention. The successful adoption of these specific criteria by the IWC has now provided the U.S.A. with a clear basis upon which to certify and sanction, under the Packwood-Magnuson and Pelly amendments, nations such as Japan, whose scientific research programs do not meet the criteria set down.

The U.S.A. certified Japan on 10 February 1988 and later announced that Japanese access to U.S.A. waters in 1988 (involving catches of 3000 tons of sea snails and 5000 tons of whiting) will be denied. All future Japanese fishing privileges will be denied until the situation is corrected. The U.S.A. decided not to restrict fisheries imports from Japan.
Australia has no legislation similar to that used by the United States to impose sanctions on Japan.

Australia considers the IWC to be the appropriate body for the international control of all whaling and the appropriate agency through which Australia should pursue international cooperation for the protection and conservation of all whales. Australia is an active member of the IWC and strongly supports the work of Australian scientists in the IWC Scientific Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 20 May 1988:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are plants registered under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 in Australia also protected overseas; if so, (a) in what countries are these plants protected; (b) when were the agreements with these overseas countries (i) negotiated, and (ii) ratified.
(2) Is the protection reciprocal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: This is the first of a series of nine questions asked by the honourable senator and I would like to say at the outset that in answer to any further questions of this nature I shall refer the honourable senator directly to the Registrar. Many of the answers are given in the Act which was debated at length by this House and others are of an administrative nature.
In answer to the specific issues:

PVR granted under the Australian Act applies only in Australia. There are no agreements with overseas countries, although this Government may work towards such an arrangement with New Zealand under the CER agreement.

Australia will be seeking membership of the International Union for the Protection of New Plant Varieties (UPOV) but this will not give automatic protection in other member countries. It gives an applicant for PVR in one member country 12 months priority over other applicants for a similar variety in other member countries. Once an application is accepted, the variety must meet the criteria established by each country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can plants that have been produced by genetic engineering be registered under the provisions of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987; if so, what are the criteria for determining whether the new plant is a species or a variety.
(2) Is a spontaneous mutant of a plant product by genetic engineering registrable under the Act; if so, who owns the rights to the mutant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) New plant varieties developed using genetic engineering are eligible for Plant Variety Rights (PVR) if they are distinct, uniform, stable (DUS criteria) and new. The variety developed this way would easily meet the requirement of being originated by a person. Genes themselves cannot be protected using PVR and the existing industrial patents system should be used.

The International Code of Botanical Nomenclature and the International Code for the Nomenclature of Cultivated Plants are used for categorising and naming species and varieties. A system of peer assessment is used to ensure applicants have correctly identified and named their plants. Varieties will not be accepted for PVR unless they belong to a described species.

(2) If a person carries out activities in relation to particular plants (regardless of the fact that the plants contain genetically engineered genes) in the hope that a new variety will emerge by natural processes (eg mutation) and a new variety does emerge, the new variety is eligible (subject to meeting the DUS and newness criteria) for PVR and the person mentioned above is the owner of the variety.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: For the purposes of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987, how are the following grouped: (a) bacteria; (b) yeasts; (c) moulds; (d) fungi; (e) algae; (f) kelps; and (g) viruses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The above groups are not eligible for PVR and are specifically excluded (with the exception of viruses) from the definition of ``plant'' under the Act. Viruses are not considered to be plants and are excluded by definition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: For the purposes of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987, what is the definition of (a) genus; (b) species; (c) strain; (d) variety.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The International Code of Botanical Nomenclature and the International Code for the Nomenclature of Cultivated Plants are used as the basis for categorising plants. Only varieties belonging to a described species will be accepted for PVR.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy publish the recommendations he receives from the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Reasons for Advisory Committee recommendations and my decisions on PVR matters of general interest will be published in the Plant Varieties Journal. Reasons for recommendations and decisions on specific applications will be given to the applicant and anyone lodging a formal objection. Further details on specific matters can be obtained from the Registrar.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What precautions exist to ensure that a spontaneous mutant of a plant discovered in the wild is not claimed as a new variety under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A spontaneous mutant from a plant discovered in the wild would be eligible for PVR if a person carried out activities in relation to particular plants in the hope that a new variety derived from those plants would originate by natural process (subsection 3 (5) of the Act). The new variety would also have to be grown through four generations or propagation cycles in cultivation to establish it as a cultivar and it must be distinct from all other known varieties, uniform and stable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can plants that are propagated solely by way of cuttings be registered as new varieties under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987.
(2) Are plants grown from cuttings clones of the original plant.
(3) What criteria exist to ensure that cloned material will breed true.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A plant variety propagated by way of cuttings is eligible for PVR if it is new, distinct from all other known varieties, uniform and stable.
(2) Plants grown from cuttings are clones of the original plant and a new variety would only occur if there was a mutation.

(3) Vegetative propagation is the most stable form of reproduction of plants and it is generally accepted that cloned plants breed true. Variation will only occur if there is a mutation. Applicants for PVR must demonstrate that the variety is stable through a least one propagation cycle. If, after PVR has been granted, there is evidence that the variety is not stable, the rights can be revoked.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Press advertisements for submissions, which closed on 12 January 1988, for new varieties of plants under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 ask for public comment on Rape (Brassica Napus).
(2) Does The Plant Varieties Journal, volume 1 no. 1, state that it is proposed to include ``Brassica SP.'' (oilseeds, rape, Mustard etc.) under the Act from March 1988.
(3) What is meant by ``Brassica Sp.'', and what plants are covered.
(4) What is meant by ``etc.'', and what plants are covered.
(5) Why was the public not given the opportunity to comment on the inclusion of mustard, and other plants in the genus Brassica.
(6) Will the Minister again refer the whole matter of ``Brassica SP.'' to the Advisory Committee to allow for public comment; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The ``Plant Varieties Journal'' states that it is proposed to include ``Brassica sp (oilseeds) (rape, mustard etc)''.

(3) & (4) The above proposal includes the species of brassica which are classed as oilseeds. The main species are Brassica napus (rape), Brassica juncea (mustard) and Brassica campestris, although any other Brassica species used for oilseed would also be included.

(5) Comments submitted on the proposed inclusion of Brassica napus indicated that there was no reason to separate the time for inclusion of the oilseed species. As this is a small, specialised group of plants it was appropriate to treat them in the same way. However, the majority of brassica belong to the species Brassica oleracea which is proposed for inclusion in January 1989 and all other Brassica species in 1990. This provides ample time for comment.

(6) The inclusion of Brassica sp will not be referred to the Advisory Committee as there has been ample opportunity for comment. The original inclusion of the specialised group of oilseed species in March 1987 was based on public comment. The majority of brassica belong to other species which are proposed for inclusion as specified in point (5) above, giving adequate time for response.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Can varieties of plants, which were developed before the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 came into force, be registered as new varieties of plants under that Act; if so, is there any date before which a plant cannot be claimed as a new variety.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A variety is ineligible for PVR if it has, with the breeder's consent, been sold at all in Australia or sold overseas for more than six years. It is therefore possible for someone to have developed a new variety prior to the introduction of the Act and still be eligible for PVR if the variety has not been sold as stated above. Under the Act ``new'' does not denote a time period but refers to commercial availability.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1988 (Hansard, page 2172), Senator Sanders asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, questions without notice arising from correspondence relating to the relabelling of South African uranium to get around Finnish and Soviet embargoes. This correspondence was provided to Senator Sanders by Jup Weber, a Greens member of the Luxembourg Parliament. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In my statement to the Parliament on 20 April I outlined the conditions under which the Australian/Euratom Agreement permits safeguards obligations to be exchanged within the jurisdiction of the European Communities. I would further note that an exchange of safeguards obligations within Europe can only be achieved with the approval of the EURATOM Safeguards Directorate (ESD) after application by the relevant organisation concerned.

(2) It is certainly not a fact that exchanges of safeguards obligations in the European Communities are privatised and unregulated. The approval of the ESD is necessary before any obligation exchange can take place. The ESD is of course an official agency of the European Commission. It is the authority which regulates movements of, and exchanges of obligations on, nuclear material. The prior consent of Australia for exchanges of safeguards obligations within EURATOM is not required provided certain conditions, set out in my statement of 20 April, are adhered to;

(3) Internal exchanges of safeguards obligations involving Australian obligated nuclear material do not alter the amount of nuclear material subject to Australian bilateral safeguards agreements. Neither do they affect the total amount of nuclear material which remains within the control of a bilateral partner country or group of countries.

International flag swaps (IFS) however have the same effect as a physical transfer of nuclear material from one safeguards jurisdiction to another. Under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements no Australian obligated nuclear material can be re-transferred from a bilateral partner's safeguards jurisdiction without Australia's prior consent. Therefore any IFS involving Australian obligated nuclear material would also require Australia's prior consent.
For these reasons IFS are different from internal exchanges of safeguards obligations and require a different set of conditions.

(4) Australian safeguards agreements do not ban exchanges of safeguards obligations on equivalent quantities of nuclear material within a jurisdiction. Their design and implementation have been successful in ensuring that obligated nuclear material subject to these agreements remains in exclusively peaceful non-explosive use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May 1988 (Hansard, page 2513), Senator Powell asked me a question without notice concerning a document about a large number of community youth support scheme (CYSS) projects in Victoria. I undertook to provide some information additional to my answer. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following information for the honourable senator:

ANSWER.PARA: In the context of the 1987/88 Budget, the Government announced its intention to integrate the three existing community programs-the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS), the Community Training Program (CTP) and the Community Volunteer Program (CVP)-into a single community training and employment assistance program. On 15 June 1988, the Minister for Employment and Education Services, Mr Duncan, announced details of the new program, to be called SkillShare. Members of Parliament and Senators have been supplied with detailed information packages about SkillShare.

The document referred to by Senator Powell is part of a preliminary examination of information about existing programs undertaken in the light of the impending introduction of SkillShare. However, it is a working document with no official status, and will not be used as the basis for any future funding decisions under the new program. Further, departmental officers were not under any direction to consider political issues during this exercise.

SkillShare has been designed to meet the needs of disadvantaged unemployed people and the local labour market, and funding priority will be given to those projects which are best able to offer activities and structured skills training to accord with SkillShare's guidelines and its emphasis on meaningful outcomes for participants. Distribution of funds will be dependent on local levels of unemployment and the needs of the local labour market, as well as the capacity of prospective sponsors to meet program objectives.

Prospective project sponsors will be invited to apply for funding in July. No decision has been taken on the continuation or otherwise of existing projects, which will be funded under current arrangements until 31 December 1988, and all applications for funding will be considered without prejudice.
Members and senators will be kept informed of the situation in relation to approval of projects in their electorates.
